title: Can this tech unicorn build the Uber of real estate?
text:
Ripe for disruption

Real estate, of course, is hideously clunky. Buyers who enter the market, at best perhaps a handful of times in their lives, are invariably hopelessly outgunned by the professional sharks that swim through the opaque rules, fees and conventions of buying and selling. In the US, most deals are hammered out between selling and buyers’ agents.

Everyone takes a piece of the action, preying on vulnerable, emotional customers. There’s so much to loathe about the process. It is a sprawling slab of the economy that is ripe for disruption.

Allon and Reffkin want to turn that story on its head – to make buying and selling seamless; to chisel away the complexity and barriers between buyers and sellers. The way Allon sees it, there’s more information to guide you on where to go to dinner – through Yelp and Google Maps – than there is to guide you on what your house is worth.

Compass’s algorithms, he says, provide fast and accurate estimates. “I think when you back it up with data and you actually help people at scale, that’s how you gain the trust of the users,” he says. The company’s so-called “north star” is “to deploy all the technology that we can think of to really help people find their place in the world. That’s a mission that a lot of people like and can relate to”.

Across America, in the front yards of houses and apartment-block windows, there’s plenty of evidence that the Compass approach is gaining traction. This correspondent has watched Compass-branded sales signs pop up like mushrooms throughout a Maryland suburb next to the District of Columbia border. A little over a year ago, such signs weren’t there.

Allon says the value of transactions Compass completes is set to double this year since 2018 to more than $US80 billion. It completed about 35,000 deals last year and is targeting 20 per cent market share across America’s 20 biggest city markets by 2020. “We’re moving faster than we anticipated, so I think we’re going to hit this target,” Allon says. In some places, like San Francisco, market share already above that goal.

A funding round for Compass in July raised an extra $US370 million, taking its investors’ total commitment to just over $US1.5 billion and producing an eye-watering valuation of $US6.4 billion as well as raising expectations for an eventual initial public offering.

All of this has helped boost 39-year-old Allon’s personal wealth, which has leapt almost 40 per cent to $747 million in the past year, according to the Financial Review Young Rich List. Allon’s stake in Compass accounts for about $600 million of that.

Advertisement

From the beginning, his has been a remarkable story – a fortune built on being the right guy, doing the right thing at the right time, in the right place. And that “right place” happened to be an Australian university.

Allon was born in Israel, his father is a journalist for the liberal Tel Aviv-based Haaretz newspaper, his mother a retired television station executive. While skirting questions about his personal life, it’s clear Allon stays close to his roots. For a telephone interview several weeks after our first one in New York, Allon breaks away from his family’s Rosh Hashanah celebrations while on a visit back to Israel.

His parents always encouraged him to “go for big things – not to settle. There’s no way I’d be where I am today without my parents, on many levels”. As a kid, Allon says he did well at academic pursuits as well as sports like surfing and basketball. At 15, he posted the second-fastest Israeli 100-metre time for his age group, clocking 11.8 seconds. Computers, maths and physics were early passions. “I knew from an early age that I’m going to stay a student for a long time.”

Life in Australia

After high school and compulsory military service, he moved to Melbourne in 2002 and completed bachelor’s and master’s degrees in computer science at Monash University before moving to the University of NSW in Sydney to do a PhD backed by an Australian Research Council grant.

During that time he became an Australian citizen – something he says he pursued “right away” after becoming convinced he would build his future there. “I was like; ‘oh my god, this place is amazing’.”

The guy searched for his wife’s name and I got her university, I got her thesis work, I got everything. He was shocked. — Ori Allon

His big break came within weeks of starting his PhD at UNSW, as he began the requisite literature review that precedes all doctoral work. Allon spotted what looked like an unexploited gap in his chosen field of internet search.

At the time, the biggest internet search engines would rank websites according to how many other sites linked to them. The young PhD candidate began thinking about how banks had become adept at mining huge stores of data by “clustering” things like the age or income of customers to sell new products.

Advertisement

“Why do we do it only on numbers and clients,” he wondered. “Why can’t we apply data mining techniques on the internet, the whole internet?”

Before he could fully test his idea, Allon needed serious computing firepower. He credits his supervisor Dr Eric Martin and UNSW’s then head of school Professor Paul Compton for securing all the resources he needed, filling his room in the School of Computer Science and Engineering with expensive servers. “They funded it and they had the foresight,” he says.

Once armed with the sufficient hardware, he set to work. Rather than typing "Australia" into Google and getting a long list of websites that mention that word, his software pulled up pages with more useful information like important cities or historical events. (For an idea of how it works, type your name into a Google search bar and watch it throw up related words.) In September 2005, UNSW announced its PhD student’s keyword-driven idea, now patented as Orion.

At a press conference in 2016 to announce Amar'e Stoudemire's signing with Allon's Hapoel Jerusalem basketball team.

And then Silicon Valley came knocking. Google flew a team, led by a top engineering executive, across the Pacific to see a demonstration. “The guy searched for his wife’s name and I got her university, I got her thesis work, I got everything. He was shocked,” Allon said.

A bidding war ensued, reportedly between Microsoft, Yahoo and Google, which won after UNSW and Allon accepted what he says was a “significant, life-changing” sum of money. The figure is subject to a non-disclosure agreement.

Moving to the US

After the deal went through in 2006 Allon moved to the US where he led a team of engineers fusing Orion into Google’s brain – a hugely complex task that took two years to complete. “We had to touch every system.”

The day the tech went live in March 2009 – the same year UNSW awarded his PhD – was one of Allon’s proudest days. “You don’t really think when you sit there and you’re like ‘oh, I have this idea that one day you’re going to turn the switch and it’s part of the most important search company in the world’. If you think about the whole journey, it kind of sounds crazy.”

Allon’s success in the US means he hasn’t been back to Australia in a decade. Yet he remains ever grateful to the universities that launched him. Monash and UNSW gave him an education as good, he says, as American Nobel laureate factories like MIT or Stanford.

Advertisement

“I can say that because I hire a lot of those guys and I know the kind of education I got ... I’m a product of Australian colleges and universities. The fact is, the most important work that I’ve ever done was in Australia.”

Which throws up a perennial question: why couldn’t the tech be commercialised here? While Telstra at one point looked at the technology, says Allon, Orion ultimately landed in the US because of the scale and depth of its tech industry.

“People here are ready to adapt and to use new technologies and they have the means to pay for them. In other places it’s just harder and slower.”

“I love Australia. I obviously became a citizen … but in terms of the opportunities in today’s world, I think America … is very hard to compete with.”

Building a legacy

Either way, the move to Google instilled in him a drive to succeed. A Mountain View engineer gave him early advice, saying it was all good and well to come up with “a clever business and then sell it to a big company” but ultimately the goal should be to build something with a legacy. Allon has been chasing that idea ever since.

He left Google in 2010, moved to New York and created another start-up, which he called Julpan, an Indigenous Australian word for Orion: “I stayed true to my Australian roots.”

After the success of Orion, Allon was able to pull in Microsoft as an early investor. The company’s 20-strong team built another search engine, this time focused on analysing social media and helping users find relevant content.

Just as Julpan was just about to launch its technology, Allon says the phone rang with an invitation to meet Twitter founder Jack Dorsey and its then CEO, Dick Costolo. Allon says he was torn between building an enduring company or selling yet again.

But having “someone offer you tens of millions of dollars” after one year of work was hard to dismiss. Not just for him, but for his co-investors and staff. “A lot of them are my friends and that’s life-changing for them as well.”

Advertisement

Twitter bought Julpan in September 2011 for an undisclosed sum, although it was reported to be its largest-ever acquisition, eclipsing the $US40 million it outlaid for TweetDeck four months earlier. Julpan’s tech is used to this day, helping users search for related tweets.

The trappings of wealth

Having scored two huge slam-dunks in a row, Allon began to enjoy some of the perks of great wealth.

His money has gone into a nightclub in Manhattan’s Little Italy called Goldbar, which has walls embedded with gold skulls. Nearby is another investment, Sweetwater Social, a sports bar off Broadway where Allon likes to watch games.

In 2013 he bought his favourite childhood basketball team Hapoel Jerusalem. His face lights up when he describes the moment they clinched their first-ever Israeli championship win two years later.

He’s since sold the team but there have been reports of his interest in buying the Boston Celtics. “Not yet,” he responds. But he has invested in his first feature film – and hints there may be a big movie name attached. Meanwhile his social media posts attest to other hobbies like jet skiing, private jet travel to exotic island locations and drone flying.

But for all the fun big money brings, Allon repeatedly brings up the quest for something bigger. “I sold two companies very quickly and think I was at a point in my life where I was like; ‘OK, I want to build a business. I want to build a real business’.”

Founding Compass

Which is how he and his partner Reffkin decided to think hard about industries they felt had been ignored by big tech and therefore were ripe for innovation. The duo chose real estate and Compass was born in early 2013. Burgeoning global investor appetite for the next tech “unicorn” as well as Allon’s track record in selling – one business to Google and another to Twitter – ensured they had no trouble raising money.

Advertisement

Investors include Goldman Sachs, the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, Fidelity, chairman and CEO of American Express Kenneth Chenault, as well as Salesforce founder Marc Benioff. In 2017, Japan’s SoftBank Group Corp bought a share.

SoftBank is headed by legendary tech investor Masayoshi Son, who has said that Compass is “going to be a great unicorn”. SoftBank's other bets include Uber and Slack, although lately it's best known for being the biggest investor in the now deeply troubled WeWork office space leasing firm.

Compass began with 20 people in a midtown office that was once the set for the TV drama Law and Order, complete with sludgy green-coloured walls. Allon is chairman and his chief executive is Reffkin, who comes across as the more polished suit-wearing salesman of the two.

Ori Allon's seven-year-old real estate portal, Compass, took on a ninth round of funding, valuing it at more than $9 billion – and increasing his personal wealth from $539 million to $747 million.

The company relentlessly hammers its upbeat “real estate reimagined” philosophy. A YouTube video of last November’s annual showcase at a glamorous theatre in Los Angeles looks like something Steve Jobs or Elon Musk would stage. Reffkin and his top executives spool out their goals and new products for the coming year as about 3000 Compass agents scream like iPhone fanatics.

Yet for all its gloss and excitement, not everyone is buying the hype. In April The Wall Street Journal described Compass as “still trying to figure out the business” and said its “free-spending ways are rattling rivals and shaking up the industry”.

Critics say that for all the technology the company deploys, the basic business model is pretty standard, with Compass providing back-office support to agents for a share of the 5 to 6 per cent per commission they get on a deal.

“If you talk to Compass agents they love the company and the brand – they have a swanky office, Reffkin is charismatic … there’s a true positive atmosphere,” Mike DelPrete, a real estate tech strategist at the University of Colorado Boulder, tells AFR Magazine. “But if you look at the economics, you scratch your head.”

In a 35-page analysis posted mid-year, DelPrete questions its “massive valuation” and whether it should be measured as a tech company or a real estate business.

He points out that others are in the race to combine the two, including Zillow, Redfin, Opendoor, Purplebricks and – perhaps ominously – recent entrant Amazon. Lawsuits have been aimed at Compass. “You can have tremendous tech [but] what is that tech doing?” DelPrete says. “My analysis is that they’re no more efficient than industry standard.”

Advertisement

A key criticism is that Compass began aggressively expanding its market share in late 2017 after a number of large funding rounds – including the money from SoftBank. That money has been deployed to buy entire brokerages and lure star agents with attractive offers that existing real estate agencies can’t match.

“Compass comes in decimating those companies,” says DelPrete. They “throw money around, they don’t have to worry about being profitable, which the family businesses have to be, and the agents leave with sweetheart deals.”

One big US east coast broker, who spoke on condition of anonymity, tells AFR Magazine he has been offered “a good bit of money” to join the company several times and believes success will depend on whether Compass can win huge market share.

“These are Wall Street people, they’re technology people. They have a great sales pitch and, to some degree, a supportive platform,” he says. But the push to eventually IPO the company – something Allon reiterates should happen in coming years – may simply end up benefiting the few “at the top”, says the broker.

Allon firmly pushes back against such attacks: the commissions Compass pays its agents are in line with market rates so the company’s attractiveness instead reflects its tech tools. Retention rates, he adds, are at “98, 99 per cent”. “They love Compass and love our tools and love the company and they want to stay here.”

Yet Wall Street’s appetite for flashy tech-based mega IPOs has soured badly of late, as investors question whether valuations are simply pumped up by today’s easy money in a low interest-rate world. High-profile stockmarket entrances by giants like Uber, Peloton and Lyft have suffered spectacular post-listing tumbles amid earnings reports filled with cash burn.

The scrutiny is one reason for the northern summer’s biggest corporate takedown – the decision by Millennial office space provider WeWork to yank its much-hyped IPO in September after investors baulked at its $US47 billion price tag.

US business pages have been buzzing with tales of corporate excess, tequila-fuelled partying and the exit of its once god-like founder, Adam Neumann.

Advertisement

Such stories aren’t good news for Compass, given the crossover with SoftBank. In late September, Compass announced the departure of its chief operating officer, Maelle Gavet. It follows recent exits by others including its general counsel, head of product and chief people officer, according to The Wall Street Journal.

When AFR Magazine speaks with Allon after the WeWork float is pulled, a note of caution has crept in. Compass is being “very responsible” and where it does expand, it is doing so at a pace “we can support with organic growth”, he says.

Compass also doesn’t “need to raise money in the foreseeable future” and, as it grows, “is spending less money and making more money. It’s a very different business than some of the others that you’ve heard about recently,” he says.

He’s also cautious when it comes to talking about geographical expansion. A couple of months ago, when we first asked Allon about plans to grow abroad, he seemed upbeat about tackling markets such as London and Sydney.

Only a few weeks later he’s saying expansion outside the US is a long-term goal for Compass. “I’m actually excited to do it, but I think it’s going to happen at the right time.”

It was rapid evolution in the tech sector that led Allon into his extraordinary life and away from Australia. Now, in an almost ironic twist, the same phenomenon could be stopping him from coming back. Australia’s real estate agencies, it seems, can rest easy. For now.

The November issue of AFR Magazine, including the Young Rich List, is out on Friday, October 25 inside The Australian Financial Review. Follow AFR Mag on Twitter and Instagram.
description: Software whiz, Manhattan club owner and Hollywood investor Ori Allon is on an audacious mission to disrupt the property sector. But will Compass ever point back to his launch pad, Australia?
